post.post_content:
Health insurance companies are required to cover some medicines used to treat HIV. If someone doesn't have health insurance, or is unable to afford the copay or co-insurance amount, they may be eligible for other government programs that can help through Medicaid, Medicare, the Ryan White Care HIV/AIDS Program, and community health centers. A health care provider or the local public health department can tell people with HIV where to get HIV treatment. +
In addition to taking ART, you can do other things to lower your risk of getting or transmitting HIV:

Use condoms the right way every time you have sex.
Talk to a health care provider to see if taking daily medicine to prevent HIV (pre-exposure prophylaxis, or PrEP) is right for you or your partner.
Talk to your health care provider right away (within 3 days) about taking medicine to prevent getting HIV (called post-exposure prophylaxis, or PEP) if you or your partner might have been recently exposed to HIV, like if the condom breaks during sex and the HIV-positive partner is not virally suppressed.
Get tested and treated for STDs and encourage your partner to do the same.

responses.resp_title: RE: U=U (Undetectable is Untransmittable)
responses.resp_content:
In an infected individual the virus would be present in menstrual blood.
The only reason that an undetectable vital load is typically determined to be less than 50 copies (or, in some types of tests, less than 5 copies) is because certain tests cannot pick up lower amounts of this virus in an infected individuals blood. This does not mean that individual is HIV negative of course; only that testing cannot pick up a viral load less than this amount.

Gail

Hi there and thanks for posting.

Here ( http://wb.md/2cGe0g1 ) is a really great resource, which answers the question, "How do I catch HIV?" I think you might find it useful. The article says that body fluids like blood can pass through broken skin, wounds, or mucous membranes but it's incredibly rare to contract the HIV virus this way. The FAQ says it's possible to get HIV through oral sex although "it's not as risky as anal or vaginal sex, but it can still happen." It also says the greatest risk is for the person who gets semen in their mouth after their partner has ejaculated.

Have you considered taking an at-home testing kit? It says here ( http://wb.md/2duk6Da ) that "you can buy a couple of different home HIV antibody tests now. They cost about $40. With the Home Access test, you prick your finger and then send a drop of blood off for testing. Like other antibody tests, it's more than 99% accurate. The results take 1 to 7 days. OraQuick is a mouth swab that gives you results in 20 minutes. It's about 92% accurate."

Ultimately, even though it might be complicated to get tested, I highly suggest that you do get tested since you did engage sexually with a person who was confirmed as HIV +.

Keep us posted! We're here for you.

responses.author: georgiagail
responses.resp_title: RE: Extremely worried
responses.resp_content:
"Technically" you will read that the recommended time period for antibody testing with the Oraquick product is 90 days after a "potential" exposure. However, in truth, 95 percent of newly infected folks will have enough antibodies present within 25 days of transmission to show a "reactive" (positive) test result. By 90 days this has increased to 99.99+ percent. 60-74 days falls somewhere inbetween these two stats.

In addition, the estimated risk of transmission for a male (from female partners) is relatively small; for insertive (that's you) unprotected penile-vaginal intercourse the estimated risk is 5 per 10,000 exposures with a partner KNOWN to carry the virus (I'm assuming this is what took place sexually). Your risk would be less since it appears you do not know if any of these partners were even HIV positive.

Sorry to toss all these stats at you but between the risk and the stats, it is highly, HIGHLY unlikely that any of these sexual encounters left you infected. In addition, the first stage of HIV, known as ARS tends to occur 2 to 6 weeks after transmission, is described as "flu like" in nature but only lasts (like the "regular" flu) for about 2 weeks. These symptoms tend to be respiratory in nature, not GI.

If you remain concerned and want to "cover all bases" (so to speak) you can, of course, take that final test at the 90 day mark from your last unprotected sexual encounter...but only to ease your anxiety.

I hope this makes sense...

Gail

responses.author: georgiagail
responses.resp_title: RE: HIV Rapid test after 6-8 years. But symptoms showing need advice desperately.
responses.resp_content:
Couple of things to keep in mind...

While one cannot diagnose HIV by "symptoms", issues such as dandruff, blurry vision and rashes have nothing to do with this disease.

As a general rule, it takes about a decade for an infected individual NOT on medication to transition from HIV into the latter stage of the disease (AIDS); until that time period their immune system continues to produce antibodies to the virus and thus any ELISA/antibody screening test would result in a "reactive" (positive) test result.

It is only when someone has reached the end stage of the disease and the immune system has been terribly ravaged by the virus that it MAY no longer be able to produce antibodies. At that point the individual often experiences severe weight loss, GI symptoms (malabsorption, diarrhea), certain types of pneumonia, often skin changes, etc. as they can no longer fight off any infection. It is this inability to fight off infections due to a lack of a functioning immune system that, eventually, causes death from this virus.

If you can't work and you can't sleep it is perhaps understandable why you are becoming fatigued and losing weight; this may explain your symptoms more than anything else. However, if you remain concerned and wish more testing, the test you should be requesting is a viral load, not more antibody testing. Viral load testing would look for the actual presence of the virus in your blood.

I hope this makes sense.

Gail

responses.author: georgiagail
responses.resp_title: RE: Very scared, and looking for answers..
responses.resp_content:
Sorry; we do not attempt to diagnose HIV (or hepatitis) by what one assumes are "symptoms". Only through testing can one know their status. However, quite frankly, ARS (the first stage of HIV) is described as "flu like" in nature; occurs two to six weeks after transmission and lasts about two weeks.

You don't have oral thrush connected with HIV. Oral candida in HIV is seen at the end stage of the disease when one has progressed from HIV onto AIDS. As a general rule (in an untreated individual) this occurs about a decade after transmission not 10 weeks later. It's also an incredibly painful medical condition. What you're seeing is the white tongue most of us have (especially in the morning when we wake up) that has made you think of thrush after your reading of symptoms on the internet.

At any rate, look at your risk this way. By four weeks post transmission, approximately 95 percent of newly infected folks will have enough antibodies present to show a "reactive" (positive) test result when undergoing antibody screening. By 12 weeks this has increased to 99.99+ percent. Your six week test falls somewhere inbetween these two and is excellent evidence that despite what you consider "symptoms" you remain HIV negative.


The bottom line is that you can retest at 12 weeks if you wish but it is HIGHLY (and I do mean highly) unusual for someone to test non-reactive at six weeks and reactive at twelve.

I hope this brings you some comfort. Now stop focusing on all those non-symptoms!

Gail

FAR more folks carry the herpes virus than HIV. Having one is absolutely no indication that one is also infected with HIV.

You are certainly not the first person who, after reading about symptoms on the internet, have convinced themselves they must be infected with this virus. Further reading only adds fuel to each that every itch, sneeze, cough, headache, joint pain, etc. is further proof of infection. Fear and sadness affects their appetite, sleep, bowel habits which only makes things worse.

When the vast, VAST majority finally get tested they are quite shocked (and hopefully happy) to learn the test results are "non-reactive"; in other words, they are not infected with the virus and that stress and worry only worsened symptoms that, in the end, had nothing to do with HIV.

Please do this as your worry over a disease you likely do NOT have seems to be eating away at you. Then come back and please let us know the results, OK?

georgiagail

The Western Blot test is used to confirm the accuracy of the initial antibody screening test. There are cases of what is known as "false positive" test results from the antibody screening tests; antibodies that RESEMBLE those seen in HIV infection but not connected with this virus. Thus the test result is a "false positive"; the individual is not infected.

A second test, known as a Western Blot needs to then be run to confirm (or rule out) whether the patient is HIV positive. If the Western Blot also comes back as "reactive" the diagnosis is confirmed; the person is HIV positive. If the Western Blot comes back as "non reactive" the person is considered to be HIV negative and the first screening test was a "false positive" result.

I hope this makes sense...

Gail

responses.author: georgiagail
responses.resp_title: RE: Hiv test result after one year
responses.resp_content:
What the literature that was included with the test result is accurate. There is always a "cut off" in terms of the results of this test. A level higher than 1 is considered a "reactive" result meaning that antibodies to HIV MAY have been found and further testing is indicated to rule HIV in or out (sometimes a person will have antibodies that resemble those seen in HIV but is not actually infected). A level lower than 1 is "nonreactive" meaning no antibodies to this disease were found. Your result of 49 means you are HIV negative. You did not have any antibodies to this disease present in your body.

By the way, you would normally have a p24 antigen result of 0 taking a test 1 year after a "potential" exposure. This antigen is only present in an infected individual during the first month or so after transmission.

I hope this test result brings you comfort and you feel comfortable enough to stop testing any further over this event.

Gail

Yes. Testing beats what folks think are "symptoms" each and every time.

Here's the time line for symptoms of HIV. Shortly (two to six weeks) after transmission, newly infected folks with undergo a short term bout of "flu like" symptoms. This is ARS. Like the "regular" flu, this lasts about two weeks.

After that, nothing, nada, zippo. No symptoms. It's really not until the virus has seriously affected the immune system that one would begin to see some serious symptoms. On average this may take as long as a decade after the initial infection to begin (in an untreated individual). One reason why so many may be walking around infected and not realize this.

It's not unusual when someone worries they may be infected to go on the internet and read about symptoms. But what they often read about are those symptoms seen in late stage HIV; when the infected person is moving into AIDS. These symptoms are not seen early on.

Does this mean that one will never have a fever or swollen lymph nodes or a cough or fatigue or loose stools or headaches, or feel just plain lousy? No; just that these symptoms have nothing to do with HIV.

I hope this makes sense...

Gail

The Let’s Stop HIV Together campaign raises awareness about HIV and its impact on the lives of all Americans, and fights stigma by showing that persons with HIV are real people—mothers, fathers, friends, brothers, sisters, sons, daughters, partners, wives, husbands, and co-workers.

More than a million people are living with HIV in the U.S., and the images and stories in this campaign are reminders that HIV does not discriminate across race, gender, or age.

We must re-double our efforts to assure that all people know about HIV, how to prevent transmission, their HIV status, and that people with HIV are linked to care, and treatment and prevention services. We can stop HIV Together—by Getting the Facts. Getting Tested. and Getting involved.

Finding out if you have an STD and getting treatment can lower your chances of getting or transmitting HIV and other STDs. If you're sexually active, you and your partners should get tested for STDs (including HIV if you're HIV-negative) regularly, even if you don't have symptoms.

Always use a condom the right way every time you have sex to protect yourself from STDs that can be transmitted through genital fluid. Here are some tips for learning to use a condom the right way. +
If you've never had hepatitis A or B or HPV and haven't been vaccinated, talk to your health care provider to see if vaccination is right for you. CDC recommends that everyone born from 1945 to 1965 get tested for hepatitis C at least once. Based on your age and other risk factors, your health care provider may recommend that you get tested for hepatitis C and can refer you for care if you learn that you're positive.

Visit CDC.gov or call 1-800-458-5231 to find places near you that offer confidential HIV testing and STD testing and treatment. Or you can send a text message from your mobile phone with your ZIP code to KnowIt (566948) and receive a return text with a testing site near you. Some sites may offer free tests.

post.post_content:
It is important that you start medical care and begin HIV treatment as soon as you are diagnosed with HIV. ART is recommended for all people with HIV, regardless of how long they've had the virus or how healthy they are. Starting ART slows the progression of HIV and helps protect your immune system. ART can keep you healthy for many years and greatly reduces your chance of transmitting HIV to sex partners if taken the right way, every day.

If you're taking ART, visit your health care provider regularly and always take your medicines as directed to keep your viral load as low as possible. If your viral load doesn't go down with ART, talk to your doctor about your treatment options or get a second opinion from a doctor who specializes in HIV. If you're HIV-negative and have an HIV-positive partner, encourage your partner to take ART the right way, every day to live a longer, healthier life and reduce the chances of transmitting HIV to you.

Use condoms the right way every time you have sex.
If you're HIV-negative, take medicine to prevent HIV (called pre-exposure prophylaxis, or PrEP).
If you're HIV-positive, take medicine to treat HIV (called antiretroviral therapy or ART).
Choose sexual activities that are lower risk for HIV than anal or vaginal sex.
Talking openly and frequently with your partner about sex can help you make decisions that may decrease your risk of getting or transmitting HIV. Learn more about how to get the conversation started

post.post_title: Prior agreement with sexual interests if you are positive
post.post_content:
Partner communication and agreements
Sharing your HIV status with your sex partners, and having them tell you their status, can help you make good decisions about sex and the strategies you use to lower the chance of getting or transmitting HIV risk.

Partners can make different kinds of choices about their sexual partnerships to try to lower their chances of getting or transmitting HIV. This includes being in a monogamous relationship, choosing partners with the same HIV status (serosorting), and having sex agreements to protect themselves and their partners from HIV.

While any of these actions can decrease the chance of getting or transmitting HIV, they are dependent upon both you and your partner accurately knowing and sharing information. For example, you may not be certain of your HIV status, or you may not want to tell your partner if you had sex outside the relationship. When accurate information isn't shared between partners, your chance of getting or transmitting HIV can actually increase.

Many factors can decrease someone's chance of getting or transmitting HIV. Abstinence is the best way to prevent getting HIV from a sex partner. For people who are sexually active, there are more tools available today to prevent HIV than ever before. Choosing less risky sexual behaviors, taking medicines to prevent and treat HIV, or using condoms with lubricants are all highly effective ways to reduce the risk of getting or transmitting HIV. Additionally, men who are circumcised have a lower chance of getting HIV from having vaginal sex than men who are not circumcised.

Reducing the number of partners you have can lower the chances that you will have a sex partner who will transmit HIV to you. There are different ways that partner communication and agreements you make with your partners can decrease your chances of getting or transmitting HIV. However, the accurate exchange of information about HIV status and sexual partners is critical for these strategies to work. Because your partner may not know their HIV status, or is unable to tell you this information, it is hard to ensure that these strategies will actually decrease your risk. In fact, these strategies may increase your risk.

new CDC Vital Signs report published today finds that HIV is being diagnosed sooner after infection than was previously reported. According to the report, the estimated median time from HIV infection to diagnosis was three years in 2015. CDC previously estimated that, in 2011, the median time from HIV infection to diagnosis was three years and seven months.

The seven-month improvement is a considerable decrease over a four-year period and reinforces other recent signs that the nation’s approach to HIV prevention is paying off.

The Vital Signs analysis also found that the percent of people at increased risk for HIV who reported getting an HIV test the previous year has increased. Despite that progress, too few are tested.

The Vital Signs analysis suggests that, without increased testing, many people living with undiagnosed HIV may not know they have HIV for many years.

Opportunistic infections (OIs) are infections that occur more frequently and are more severe in individuals with weakened immune systems, including people with HIV. OIs are less common now than they were in the early days of HIV and AIDS because better treatments reduce the amount of HIV in a person’s body and keep a person’s immune system stronger. However, many people with HIV still develop OIs because they may not know of their HIV infection, they may not be on treatment, or their treatment may not be keeping their HIV levels low enough for their immune system to fight off infections.

For those reasons, it is important for individuals with HIV to be familiar with the most common OIs so that they can work with their healthcare provider to prevent them or to obtain treatment for them as early as possible

post.post_title: Can you take prep after being HIV exposed?
post.post_content:
PrEP (pre-exposure prophylaxis) is only for people who are at ongoing very high risk of HIV infection. But PEP (post-exposure prophylaxis) is an option for someone who thinks they’ve recently been exposed to HIV during sex or through sharing needles and works to prepare drugs.

PEP means taking antiretroviral medicines after a potential exposure to HIV to prevent becoming infected. PEP must be started within 72 hours of possible exposure to HIV. If you’re prescribed PEP, you’ll need to take it once or twice daily for 28 days.

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content:
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (or PrEP) is when people at very high risk for HIV take HIV medicines daily to lower their chances of getting infected. PrEP can stop HIV from taking hold and spreading throughout your body. It is highly effective for preventing HIV if used as prescribed, but it is much less effective when not taken consistently.

Daily PrEP reduces the risk of getting HIV from sex by more than 90%. Among people who inject drugs, it reduces the risk by more than 70%. Your risk of getting HIV from sex can be even lower if you combine PrEP with condoms and other prevention methods.

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content: The risk of getting HIV varies widely depending on the type of exposure or behavior (such as sharing needles or having sex without a condom). Some exposures to HIV carry a much higher risk of transmission than other exposures. For some exposures, while transmission is biologically possible, the risk is so low that it is not possible to put a precise number on it. But risks do add up over time. Even relatively small risks can add up over time and lead to a high lifetime risk of getting HIV. In other words, there may be a relatively small chance of acquiring HIV when engaging in a risk behavior with an infected partner only once; but, if repeated many times, the overall likelihood of becoming infected after repeated exposures is actually much higher.

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content:
Can I Get HIV from Casual Contact, Using a Public Space, or from a Mosquito Bite?

No. HIV is NOT transmitted:

By hugging, shaking hands, sharing toilets, sharing dishes, or closed-mouth or “social” kissing with someone who is HIV-positive.
Through saliva, tears, or sweat that is not mixed with the blood of an HIV-positive person.
By mosquitoes, ticks or other blood-sucking insects.
Through the air.
As noted above, only certain body fluids—blood, semen, pre-seminal fluid, rectal fluids, vaginal fluids, and breast milk—from an HIV-infected person can transmit HIV. Most commonly, people get or transmit HIV through sexual behaviors and needle or syringe use. Babies can also get HIV from an HIV-positive mother during pregnancy, birth, or breastfeeding.

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content:
You can get or transmit HIV only through specific activities. Most commonly, people get or transmit HIV through sexual behaviors and needle or syringe use.

Only certain body fluids—blood, semen, pre-seminal fluid, rectal fluids, vaginal fluids, and breast milk—from a person who has HIV can transmit HIV. These fluids must come in contact with a mucous membrane or damaged tissue or be directly injected into the bloodstream (from a needle or syringe) for transmission to occur. Mucous membranes are found inside the rectum, vagina, penis, and mouth.

In the United States, HIV is spread mainly by

Having anal or vaginal sex with someone who has HIV without using a condom or taking medicines to prevent or treat HIV.
For the HIV-negative partner, receptive anal sex (bottoming) is the highest-risk sexual behavior, but you can also get HIV from insertive anal sex (topping).
Either partner can get HIV through vaginal sex, though it is less risky for getting HIV than receptive anal sex.
Sharing needles or syringes, rinse water, or other equipment (works) used to prepare drugs for injection with someone who has HIV. HIV can live in a used needle up to 42 days depending on temperature and other factors.
Less commonly, HIV may be spread

From mother to child during pregnancy, birth, or breastfeeding. Although the risk can be high if a mother is living with HIV and not taking medicine, recommendations to test all pregnant women for HIV and start HIV treatment immediately have lowered the number of babies who are born with HIV.
By being stuck with an HIV-contaminated needle or other sharp object. This is a risk mainly for health care workers.
In extremely rare cases, HIV has been transmitted by

Oral sex—putting the mouth on the penis (fellatio), vagina (cunnilingus), or anus (rimming). In general, there’s little to no risk of getting HIV from oral sex. But transmission of HIV, though extremely rare, is theoretically possible if an HIV-positive man ejaculates in his partner’s mouth during oral sex. To learn more about how to lower your risk, see CDC’s Oral Sex and HIV Risk.
Receiving blood transfusions, blood products, or organ/tissue transplants that are contaminated with HIV. This was more common in the early years of HIV, but now the risk is extremely small because of rigorous testing of the US blood supply and donated organs and tissues.
Eating food that has been pre-chewed by an HIV-infected person. The contamination occurs when infected blood from a caregiver’s mouth mixes with food while chewing. The only known cases are among infants.
Being bitten by a person with HIV. Each of the very small number of documented cases has involved severe trauma with extensive tissue damage and the presence of blood. There is no risk of transmission if the skin is not broken.
Contact between broken skin, wounds, or mucous membranes and HIV-infected blood or blood-contaminated body fluids.
Deep, open-mouth kissing if both partners have sores or bleeding gums and blood from the HIV-positive partner gets into the bloodstream of the HIV-negative partner. HIV is not spread through saliva

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content:
The following criteria are used to determine if a person with HIV has AIDS:
The person’s immune system is severely damaged, as indicated by a CD4 count of less than 200 cells/mm3. A CD4 count measures the number of CD4 cells in a sample of blood. The CD4 count of a healthy person ranges from 500 to 1,600 cells/mm3.
AND/OR
The person has developed certain opportunistic infections.

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content:
Without treatment with HIV medicines, HIV infection usually advances to AIDS in 10 years or longer, though it may take less time for some people.

HIV transmission is possible at any stage of HIV infection—even if a person with HIV has no symptoms of HIV.

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content:
Within 2 to 4 weeks after a person becomes infected with HIV, they may have flu-like symptoms, such as fever, chills, or rash. The symptoms may last for a few weeks after they become infected.

After this earliest stage of HIV infection, HIV continues to multiply but at very low levels. More severe symptoms of HIV infection, such as signs of opportunistic infections, generally don’t appear for many years. (Opportunistic infections are infections and infection-related cancers that occur more frequently or are more severe in people with weakened immune systems than in people with healthy immune systems.)

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content:
Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is the use of HIV medicines to treat HIV infection. People on ART take a combination of HIV medicines (called an HIV regimen) every day. (HIV medicines are often called antiretrovirals or ARVs.)

ART prevents HIV from multiplying and reduces the amount of HIV in the body. Having less HIV in the body protects the immune system and prevents HIV infection from advancing to AIDS.

ART can’t cure HIV, but it can help people with HIV live longer, healthier lives. ART also reduces the risk of HIV transmission.

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content: You can’t get HIV by shaking hands or hugging a person who has HIV. You also can’t get HIV from contact with objects such as dishes, toilet seats, or doorknobs used by a person with HIV. HIV does not spread through the air or through mosquito, tick, or other insect bites.

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content:
HIV is spread through contact with certain body fluids from a person with HIV. These body fluids include:
Blood
Semen
Pre-seminal fluid
Vaginal fluids
Rectal fluids
Breast milk
The spread of HIV from person to person is called HIV transmission. The spread of HIV from a woman with HIV to her child during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding is called mother-to-child transmission of HIV.

In the United States, HIV is spread mainly by having sex with or sharing drug injection equipment with someone who has HIV. To reduce your risk of HIV infection, use condoms correctly and consistently during sex, limit your number of sexual partners, and never share drug injection equipment.

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_content:
HIV stands for human immunodeficiency virus, which is the virus that causes HIV infection. The abbreviation “HIV” can refer to the virus or to HIV infection.

AIDS stands for acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. AIDS is the most advanced stage of HIV infection.

HIV attacks and destroys the infection-fighting CD4 cells of the immune system. The loss of CD4 cells makes it difficult for the body to fight infections and certain cancers. Without treatment, HIV can gradually destroy the immune system and advance to AIDS.

post.post_content:
HIV is the virus that causes HIV infection. AIDS is the most advanced stage of HIV infection.
HIV is spread through contact with the blood, semen, pre-seminal fluid, rectal fluids, vaginal fluids, or breast milk of a person with HIV. In the United States, HIV is spread mainly by having anal or vaginal sex or sharing drug injection equipment with a person who has HIV.
Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is the use of HIV medicines to treat HIV infection. People on ART take a combination of HIV medicines (called an HIV regimen) every day.
ART can’t cure HIV infection, but it can help people with HIV live longer, healthier lives. HIV medicines can also reduce the risk of transmission of HIV.

responses.author: georgiagail
responses.resp_title: RE: Oral Thrush and HIV
responses.resp_content:
Thrush is a symptom seen at the END stage of HIV (i.e., when the immune system has been terribly damaged by the virus). It is not a symptom seen when someone has been infected for less than a week.

The "flu like" symptoms of early onset HIV (ARS) tends to occur two to six weeks after transmission; again not from an event that took place last week.

Hopefully your test results will show a "non-reactive" (negative) status. However, promise yourself that from now on unless you have CLEAR evidence that your partners are STD free (and not just HIV free) such sexual events will involve the appropriate use of a latex condom, OK?

Gail

Someone who was recently infected (and likely not yet producing many antibodies) would have an extremely high viral load. Viral load testing typically doesn't come with "zero" copies cut off; they will have a cut off that might say "less than 20 copies" or might say "less than 5 copies" depending on the test used. Keep in mind that HIV is an EXTREMELY delicate virus outside of the body. Picking your nose, drying your genital area with the same hand that fingered her would NOT transmit the virus to you.

You did ALL the right things; you had PROTECTED vaginal intercourse with this woman. Instead of focusing on issues that would not/could not/did not transmit the virus to you, focus on what you did right and stop worrying about this.

Gail

It's rather amazing the symptoms people develop when they start to read about these connected with HIV.

Here is the actual timeline with this disease...

Shortly (2 to 6 weeks) after transmission, newly infected folks will experience what is described as "flu like" symptoms. Like the regular flu these will last about 2 weeks.

After that, nothing until the virus has severely damaged the immune system. On average this will take up to a decade after the initial transmission. Thus when folks begin to post a bunch of symptoms shortly after a potential exposure it's often a sure bet they've spent some time reading about symptoms seen at the end of the disease on the internet. Fear of the disease often makes things much worse for them. For some this fear can become crippling.

In the end, testing beats any symptoms hands down. Your 84 day test results will come back as "non-reactive" (negative); same thing as the previous test did. Please come back and let us know the result, OK.? In the meantime try not to focus on what you believe are symptoms associated with a disease you do not have.

Good luck...

post.post_content: In some cases, formation of antibodies in hiv infection is delayed due to certain reasons. How to test such cases.

responses.author: georgiagail
responses.resp_title: RE: Delayed antibody formatin cases
responses.resp_content:
The vast, vast majority of newly infected individuals will have enough antibodies present to show a "reactive" (positive) test result within the first month after transmission. The commonly used 4th generation screening tests will also check for the presence of the p24 antigen; present in the first month after transmission. Thus, even if antibodies are not yet high enough in the blood due to early testing, the presence of this antigen would indicate the need for further testing (Western Blot) to rule the diagnosis of HIV in or out.

Keep in mind that these 4th generation tests are considered to be 99.99 percent accurate. If one is still not convinced of a negative status they may continue antibody testing at the three month mark.

Someone who is unable to produce ANY antibodies is going to be a person who is extremely ill anyway. If, for example, this person is perhaps thought to be in the later stages of the disease (i.e., has gone from HIV into AIDS) then actual viral load tests can be performed.

I hope this makes sense.

Gail

responses.author: WebMD Morgan
responses.resp_title: RE: I have HIV/AIDS
responses.resp_content:
Hi there, blueoystercultfan. I'm so sorry to hear about this. Have you spoken to your doctor about your treatment options? Early treatment is key. While there is no cure for HIV/AIDS, you can read about the treatment options available to you here: http://wb.md/2cOLabV . It is important for you to know that HIV/AIDS is no longer a death sentence and it is possible for you to live a long and productive life if you make healthy lifestyle choices and develop a treatment plan that is best for you.

Due to the stigma surrounding HIV/AIDS, someone who has just received a diagnosis might feel full of shame and as if they are completely alone, which makes it all the more difficult to verbalize your status to those closest to you. Telling your friends and family your status is a big step and one that you need to be ready for. Here (http://wb.md/2d5yIEg) is a great resource about things you should consider when telling your loved ones about your status. A helpful insight from this article is that if someone had unprotected sex with you, knowing that they were infected, then you might have legal recourse against them. I suggest speaking to a law official who is educated on the laws in your state.

More support & resources: http://wb.md/2cR1s2w.

You are NOT alone, and although this is a life changing diagnosis, it is possible to live with and manage the virus. Most of all, there is hope.

We're here for you ((hugs))

There are certain STD's/STI's that are easy to pass around, requiring only contact with skin or mucous membranes for transmission. Trich is one of these. HIV on the other hand is one of THE hardest to transmit to another human being. Transmission requires that the virus must be able to actually ENTER the body; typically through an open (i.e., bleeding) cut, wound, damaged mucous membrane, injection site, etc.. Even swallowing the sexual fluids of an infected individual would not transmit the virus to someone as the very strong stomach acids would simply dissolve the virus.

It is therefore important not to assume that picking up one of the more common sexual diseases does not mean you are also infected with HIV. Really.

Gail

responses.author: georgiagail
responses.resp_title: RE: HIV from toilet spots?
responses.resp_content:
1. No.
2. No.

HIV is an EXTREMELY delicate virus outside of the body; typically living seconds outside the confines of the warmth of the human body. This is good news.
Even IF this was blood AND this came from the former HIV tenant AND it contained any virus two years later it would be long dead. It cannot survive for any length of time in dried blood.

It would be useful to spend a little time learning how HIV is passed from one person to another. Even getting fresh blood on your toes from a positive individual and then on your underwear would not transmit the virus to you via your penis.

Gail

post.post_content:
I am going for a renal surgery. So, doctor told me to do many tests.
Out of which, he told to do HIV-1 RNA Quantitative test (Real Time PCR). The specimen is EDTA whole blood.

I got the result as

responses.author: robertjoseph092
responses.resp_title: RE: How to read the HIV-1 RNA Quantitative test result
responses.resp_content:
I got the result as <36 Copies/ml.

The technical note given in the result is: This test is an in vitro nucleic acid amplification test for the quantitation of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) RNA in human plasma. The detection limit is 36 copies / ml. Conversion factor: 1 IU/ml corresponds to 0.50 copies / ml

I don't know how to read this result.
Does the result mean that, I am infected with HIV-1 virus.
Please help me to understand the result.

responses.author: georgiagail
responses.resp_title: No; it means you are not infected with HIV. This test checks for the "viral load" (amount of virus) found in the blood of an individual infected with this virus. In an untreated individual (one who is infected but not on medication) the number of "copies" (amount of virus) would typically be extremely high (often in the thousands/ hundreds of thousands).
responses.resp_content:
The "cut off" for this test is 36 copies per ml of blood. Your result was less than 36 copies per ml of blood. In reality it actually was 0 copies per ml of blood because you're not infected with this virus but the test doesn't come back with this reading and this can be confusing and frightening to folks not used to this.
Anyway; this is long winded but the bottom line is, you don't have HIV.

Gail

"Most meningitis is caused by bacteria and viruses that often live in our bodies. Usually these germs stay in the intestines or in the nose and throat, where they may or may not make us sick. But if they spread to the tissues (meninges ) that surround the brain and spinal cord, they cause inflammation. This inflammation is called meningitis.

responses.author: georgiagail
responses.resp_title: RE: HIV possible exposure
responses.resp_content:
The 4th generation DUO test would include testing for the p24 antigen which would be present within (only) the first 28 days in an infected individual. Thus this test would be considered fairly accurate if taken within this time period. Keep in mind that up to 95 percent of newly infected folks would have enough antibodies present by 25 days after transmission to have a "reactive" (positive) test result. By 90 days this has increased to 99.99+ percent. It is extremely rare (and only in cases where one is already ill from other immune suppressing diseases) to require six month testing.

Gail

responses.author: WebMD Morgan
responses.resp_title: RE: I'm HIV + and my partner is HIV -
responses.resp_content:
Hi there and thanks for posting.

Glad to hear that you're sticking to your treatment plan and that your viral load is undetectable. I also want to commend you on practicing safe sex with your partner. I suggest that you continue to do so until you have an in-depth conversation with your doctor about ways to protect your partner from the HIV virus.

Luckily, with modern medicine, there are developments in preventative HIV treatment. You should ask your doctor about pre-exposure prophylaxis, which is commonly known as PrEP. This drug is used to prevent the infection in those who engage in high-risk sex. This news article ( http://wb.md/2dmXLTn) says that, "during a year of taking pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), only two people out of more than 400 high-risk people became infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. And it seems that those who became infected didn't take the medication properly," the study said.

These are ground breaking developments, but only your doctor will be able to tell you if PrEP is right for you and your partner.

Please continue to be safe. Be sure to update us once you've spoken to your doctor. We're here for you!

responses.author: WebMD Morgan
responses.resp_title: RE: Scared of exposure
responses.resp_content:
Hi there kandiraynee. I understand your concern. It says here ( http://wb.md/2dnbgmw ) that while the risk of transmission of HIV/AIDS during oral sex is lower than other types of sex, it is possible to get HIV by having oral sex with either a man or a woman who is HIV-positive even if the risk is low. Do you know the status of the man who you performed oral sex on?

If you are sexually active, it is hard to entirely eliminate your risk of exposure. However, there are ways to prevent it. You can read more about how to lower your HIV risk here: http://wb.md/2dgnTno .

I suggest discussing your possibility of being exposed to HIV/AIDS with your doctor. He/she will be able to best guide you in how to proceed moving forward including providing information about how and when to test for the virus and how to lower the risk of exposure in the future.

Be sure to keep us updated.

We care about you and we are here for you, even if it's just to listen.

"1.Would you reccomend for duo or pcr if I were your patient ?"

No

No

" 4.Have you seen any case personally when patient was infected but antibody did not present after 3 months?"

No
